title: 105_hr3573
content: Limitation on disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to certain countries. Section 5302 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to foreign countries not in compliance with IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot exceed $500,000,000 for international rescue plans unless the country meets IMF commitments on economic, market access, and financial reforms. The Secretary of the Treasury must consider all expenditures, loans, obligations, or guarantees made through the stabilization fund for a foreign entity in the 6-month period before any new transaction to determine if it exceeds the limitation imposed. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on US actions to monitor foreign government compliance with commitments made to the IMF in financial assistance packages. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on US efforts to monitor foreign government compliance with IMF commitments in financial assistance packages in Asia. This includes actions taken by the US Executive Director at the IMF and the Department of the Treasury, in coordination with other agencies, to enforce these commitments. The Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with the United States Trade Representative, will monitor Asian countries receiving financial assistance to ensure compliance with international agreements on market access. Reports will be submitted to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated, including progress on resolving trade disputes with countries like South Korea. The Trade Representative identified barriers in Korea denying access to foreign automobiles. Progress on trade obligations with Korea and Indonesia's compliance with ending the "National Car" program will be reported. Implementation of IMF reforms on corporate governance is also assessed. The curr_chunk discusses the need for transparency in corporate practices, prevention of financial failure through government subsidies, and implementation of IMF reform measures for deregulation and privatization. It also includes a description of trade policies and any unfair trade practices affecting the United States. The curr_chunk discusses monitoring exports from Asian countries receiving financial assistance to assess market access by Japan, the EU, and IMF participants. It also addresses enforcement actions for failure to implement international trade agreements. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor exports from Asian countries receiving financial assistance to assess market access by Japan, the EU, and IMF participants. The Secretary will report to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated and take action to ensure fair burden-sharing in response to the financial crisis in Asia. Additionally, the Commerce Department will monitor exports to the United States from these countries to determine any significant surges. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor exports from Asian countries receiving financial assistance to the United States for any significant increase due to currency fluctuations, subsidies, dumping, or transshipment. Reports will be provided to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated, and appropriate action will be taken if dumping or subsidization harms US industries. The Secretary of Commerce will consult with import-sensitive US industries to monitor and report on dumping or subsidization causing harm. The Secretary, along with the US Trade Representative, will annually report to Congress on the impact of financial assistance on trade relations between Asian countries and others. SEC. 4. FULL ENFORCEMENT OF TRADE LAW REMEDIES. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study with import-sensitive US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will address fluctuations in exchange rates and the treatment of government-induced low-interest loans under US laws. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study on the application of countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will determine the treatment of government-induced low-interest loans and subsidies received in the past under US laws. The report to Congress is due within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. SUNSET. The provisions of this Act will expire 8 years after its enactment.
